context: Such reactions are less probable in the unsaturated zone unless suitable reducing conditions develop. Recent research has focused on abiotic (and biotic) reductive dechlorination of CAHs by natural organic matter, sulphides and mineral surfaces that may act as electron donors, mediators or carriers. Abiotic reaction research has concerned iron-bearing minerals, including iron sulphide (pyrite), troilite, mackinawite and iron oxide minerals (e.g., magnetite) that may transform CAHs to non-chlorinated products (ethyne, ethene and ethane) (Ferrey et al., 2004; Lee and Batchelor, 2002a,b). PCE, TCE, CT, cDCE, 1,1-DCE have all been shown to dechlorinate abiotically. Abiotic reactions of green rust ([FeII6−x FeIII x (OH)12] x+[(A) x/n yH2O] x−) produced in natural or engineered systems has high reactivity with pseudo first-order rates 3 to 8 fold greater than pyrite producing ethyne and a lack of chlorinated intermediates (Lee and Batchelor, 2002b). Abiotically reactive ferrous (FeII) solid phases may be produced at sites from microbial activity. Although abiotic reactivity of VOCs is reasonably understood, there is potential for reaction parameter data (e.g.

The focus is on the abiotic reactions involving various electron donors and the transformation of chlorinated aliphatic hydrocarbons (CAHs) rather than on the specific roles of these two chemicals.
